content: This is from a couple of weeks ago - it is just a few lemmas about two-element sets, so I don't think review will be difficult.

My only hesitation is Set.pair_subset_iff being a simp lemma. It seems fine on the face of it, but docs#Set.insert_subset_iff isn't a simp lemma at the moment, which if it were Set.pair_subset_iff would be proved by simp.

Does anyone know what's going on with this part of the simp set?
Maybe the reason is to avoid an explosion when dealing with insert ... \subset insert ...?
That and also the fact that sometimes you want s ⊆ t ∧ a ∈ t and sometimes you want a ∈ t ∧ s ⊆ t
Does this settle things? I can remove the simp if needed.

Actually you should remove the simp for a (arguably not so) different reason: {a, b} ⊆ s ↔ a ∈ s ∧ b ∈ s is not an "affine simp lemma", namely a lemma where every free variable occurs at most as many times on the RHS as on the LHS (here, s appears twice on the RHS and once on the LHS)
In practice, non-affine simp lemma have the possibility of blowing up exponentially the size of a goal
Fair enough - removed! Things should now be good to go.
